title: SOX2 <italic>O</italic>-GlcNAcylation alters its protein-protein interactions and genomic occupancy to modulate gene expression in pluripotent cells
abstract: The transcription factor SOX2 is central in establishing and maintaining pluripotency. The processes that modulate SOX2 activity to promote pluripotency are not well understood. Here, we show SOX2 is <italic>O</italic>-GlcNAc modified in its transactivation domain during reprogramming and in mouse embryonic stem cells (mESCs). Upon induction of differentiation SOX2 <italic>O</italic>-GlcNAcylation at serine 248 is decreased. Replacing wild type with an <italic>O</italic>-GlcNAc-deficient SOX2 (S248A) increases reprogramming efficiency. ESCs with <italic>O</italic>-GlcNAc-deficient SOX2 exhibit alterations in gene expression. This change correlates with altered protein-protein interactions and genomic occupancy of the <italic>O</italic>-GlcNAc-deficient SOX2 compared to wild type. In addition, SOX2 <italic>O</italic>-GlcNAcylation impairs the SOX2-PARP1 interaction, which has been shown to regulate ESC self-renewal. These findings show that SOX2 activity is modulated by <italic>O</italic>-GlcNAc, and provide a novel regulatory mechanism for this crucial pluripotency transcription factor.
